 That is kinda a cop out answer, because someone can always come back with Nietzsche's argument:
 
 P1: If God exists, then evil can't exist
 P2: Evil exists
 Con: Therefore God can't exist.
 
 Premise one is deducted by the Christian understanding of God: God is omnibenevolent, all-knowing and omnipotent being who created ex nihilo and therefore created everything. Now if God is all powerful and all knowing and all good, he would know how to create the most ideal world where no evil would exist. Therefore he it would NECESSITATE HIM creating a world where evil would not exist. After all evil cannot be considered good, they are opposites, and God could not allow evil to exist, again, he created ex nihilo
 
 Also if you actually read all of Job and take it in context you will see God's response of "all is wise, all is mysterious, I do what I do for the greater good which you can not yet see," as being a pathetic answer when you look back at what his REAL motivation was: Job 1:9-12 and Job 2:3-7.
 
 Basically: God was bragging about Job and Satan said, "ohh yeah, well let me have him" and God was like "All right, you may test him." And that was what Satan did. I mean, it was almost something out of Trading Places, the "gentlemen's wager." If you think I am distorting or making this up, feel free to go back to the passages and read for yourself!

 From past discussions regarding this exact topic --
 
 
God being all knowing considers making a man, he looks into this man's future and sees that if this man is made he will eventually find his way back to God, God makes/forms/constructs the man content in the knowledge that the mortal will of his own will return to and love his creator.
 
 God considers making another man, again God looks into the man's future and sees the man will never find his way back to God and will become ever more disheartened with life and die after much suffering. God pauses and being a God of love is upset for this man he might make who will never find his way back to Him.
 
 Now for some strange unkown reason this God of love descides it'll be a 'good idea' to make this man anyway despite knowing the man will never find his way back to his creator and will suffer greatly in his existance.
 
 The question is why?

 
 

 Yes only God can answer why He on purpose creates people when he already knows before creating them that they will suffer and not find their way to him!
 
 He knows yet this 'loving' God does it anyway!
 
 This 'loving' God then judges these people even though he knew before creating them that they would not find their way back to him!
 
 This God contradicts the loving nature the Bible describes doesn't He?
 
 So either the Bible is wrong about God being all knowing or it is wrong about this God being a 'loving God'.
 
 Or of course He might not in fact exist at all making the Bible wrong and God non existant...

you all seem to be missing the crux of my argument. To say that free will is god's "greatest" gift is one thing, but can a good god, who is completely and totally good, create evil? It is impossible. Evil is wholly outside of God, and if nothing exists (thus the ex nihilo section) then how can evil be created if not by God?
 
 This argument just blows away the traditional understanding of God as being "all good" or "all powerful" or "all knowing". We are not able to tell which one goes, just that AT LEAST ONE of them must go. Of course Christian understanding would say that none of them must go.
 
 The Catholic Church does have an interesting solution to this dilemma found in St. Augustine (Confessions 7:3-5).... deny that evil exists. Evil is the nothingness from which God created good. Evil is a lack... a deficiently of goodness (or God), to quote a leading Augustinian scholar, P.M. Farrell:"evil is described as privation of good... Privation is real - blindness, the lack of limb, the passing of colour from the decaying rose. This description will be found to be valid of evil universally."
 
 Now this is A reasonable explanation, but it would be of no comfort to evangelical/fundamentalist Christians who view evil as something that does exist (read Satan). Which means, that for those who do not want to take the Catholic exit strategy, my evil argument still holds water.
Nwarth

Hm, I thought I was clear when I said "the Christian understanding of God" as not being the Biblical God, but how the Christian community (including fundies) have come to understand God. Which is a version of the "God of Philosophers." I am basically challenging everyone' understanding by raising obvious claims against it, claims even Augustine noticed and wrote about (with the aforementioned solution). So wraith, this isn't my interpretation, nor is it the biblical god, it is the broad, general Christian community's understanding, as expressed in people such as John Hick and churches around the country.

 you all seem to be missing the crux of my argument. 

 
 Sorry, we got side tracked.
 
 But yes the proposition that 'evil' is simply the lack of 'god' is interesting.
 
 So instead of good and evil we have simply have 'god' and 'no god'.
 
 So a human could call god evil and a human might have a point (god causing unnecessary suffering for example) but god doesn't define evil the way we do instead he considers it a 'lack of Himself'.
 
 [Could god kill himself and thusly commit an act of 'evil' -- producing a situation with a 'lack of god'? ;) ]
 
 All this leads me to wonder why acts like 'lying' are considered 'evil' -- the biblical god makes use of lying spirits, and the bible stresses it is not by actions that 'we' are saved, so at the end of the day what is the biblical god's motivations for restricting human behaviour via (for example) the 10 commandments.
 
 I can only think the biblical god deliberately chose ideals of behaviour (like not lying) he knew would be very hard for humans to stick to and thus he would be able to 'rank' humans on how well they've kept to these completely arbitrary behavioural codes and use the results to place the most 'strong willed' humans in positions of power in the post resurrection age.
 
 It's like the Biblical god is saying "Hey, salvation is a free gift you just need to accept by believing in me, but if you fancy REALLY being a powerful guy in the post ressurection age to come I've got this little competition going where by you follow these rules and the guy who manages to follow them best above all else get's the best 'positions of authority'."

Big Orn

We cannot contain God in our perception of life, therefore, we cannot judge His actions based on our cradle-to-the-grave mentality. There is no opposite of God even though there are numerous oppositions to Him. Evil is the opposite of good - in simple terms, but there is much more to evil and good than mere perceptions of simplicity.
 First of all, we can see good and evil and judge it accordingly in respect to our character, which, in this case, is our frame of mind. Once we establish what we deem to be good and evil, then is takes drastic measures to change our views, which would leave the door open for either spiritual phenomenon or logical means. If we delve in to the spiritual aspects and do so with the desire to learn more (and have the mental capability to comprehend it) then we force ourselves to test it and see if it works, then how it works and by whom or we take the logical approach and reason with it. Either way before we can make a decision we have to examine the evidence.
 
 Now, back to the topic. Paul said in Romans 8:28 (paraphrased): "We know that all things (good and evil) work together for the good for those that love God, to those that are the called according to His purpose." God uses Evil to bring about Good because He sees the "big picture". Why does Evil need to be part of the picture? Because without the evil that Satan is and without those powers of darkness there is no way that man, who has the gift of free will, could know God. Many have said that if God was good, then evil would have been destroyed in much the same way we destroy fireants that we see gathering around our homes, but it's not the same thing. God needs us to make up our own minds whether or not to follow him. We don't necessarily have to join the evil forces to become lost and undone; we would simply have to turn away from God. In this way he allows us to go through hard times, allows evil to work us over, but in the end, it brings us closer to Him - and not because He's a sadistic entity that loves pain, but because He loves us and wants us to know Him on our own terms.
 
 And as far as Judas Iscariot goes, God knew the spirit and soul of Judas; He knew that Judas loved that little ride he was taking with the other disciples - that ride full of miracles and wonders. And He also knew that when it came time for Satan to tempt Him, that Judas' character could not withstand the dark enticement and would fall prey to it. God did not foreordain Judas to be evil; He just knew Judas...period.

 the definition of omnipotent has been "toned down" to now mean "the ability to do anything that is possible". therefore, the ability to create a round square would not be a requirement for an omnipotent god. the problem now is "what EXACTLY is possible?" but thats another discussion.
 
 anyway, god has been known to change the laws of morality. there were times when killing was the righteous thing to do, and showing mercy was a sin punishable by death (joshua 7, 1 samuel 15). also, god commanded his people to steal, plunder, take slaves, and a number of what we would consider bad deeds. if you really think about it, morality is nothing more than obeying what god says (or more accurately, what the prophets/preachers/bible tells you god says). of course the problem is that since sometimes god might say something totally contrary to what he said before (like thou shalt not steal/take the jewelry from the egyptians), you really never know what is morally right at any point in time, unless you have somebody/something available update you on what god said

No. What I have stated is what I gather from the Bible and is my opinion of what that gathering means, which is, that God knew that person's character and what type of decisions that person makes under certain circumstances. Even though it is impossible to fathom God's infinite wisdom, I believe that He surpasses our thoughts processes by an indefinite amount. Being that as it is, and knowing that an analyst can make very close statistical estimates via process observation and data compilation then it would not be surprising that God would know the spirit of a person that has been the same way for millennia, would it?

therefore god could be surprised if someone makes a decision that he doesnt expect.

 I ask again: If God has already made our decisions for us, why, in the Bible, does it say He was angered by a person's choice?
 
the best god can do is a highly educated guess that could still be wrong

 I disagree on the grounds that there is no guesswork involved in His thought processes. His plan was/is developed from what took place in Heaven those many, many years ago, when His creation chose to go against His will. How we go about getting from point A to point B in that plan depends on us, individually.
 
 Still, despite the individual, the whole of mankind will end up at point B...because the Bible tells us so.
Big Orn

Basically, either
 
 1) God can predict for certain at the moment of creation, and therefore chooses for Judas
 
 2) God cannot predict for certain at the moment of creation, and therefore doesn't choose for Judas

 Both 1 and 2 are wrong. God does not have to predict anything. If He did predict - anything - it would come to pass, regardless.

 I retain my position that the Bible contradicts itself when it describes the capabilities of it's God.
 
 He can provide 'free will' to humans etc but when He knows a humans future before he makes them and hence has the choice whether to go ahead and make them or not such 'freedom of will' is an illusion.
 
 What's frustrating for me of course is how I fail to see how you logically over come this biblical contradiction.

 Removing the concept of 'absolute foreknowledge' gets around the logical contradiction between free will and predestination. Not, of course, that it makes it any more true, but at least it removes the 'round square' concept.

What's frustrating for me of course is how I fail to see how you logically over come this biblical contradiction.

 I think it has a lot to do with faith and how it has proven to be a great resource when dealing with God and His ways. It has also made it plain to me why Jesus used parables sometimes; it's hard to explain things spiritually.
 God's ultimate job is to complete His plan, which is to allow His creation to live in a world where the freedom to choose Life or Death, Good or Evil is their prerogative. This way they are responsible for which direction their life takes and Who will be their God. It is not known to man how glorifying God can be accomplished completely, because man can't seem to get past the "why" of it. Once we are with Him, we'll definitely understand it and see it plain as day. It would do God no good to manipulate our thoughts, even though He could do so very easily.

 Yes, that is what I believe and how I perceive "free will". Either it's free or it's not...bottom line.
 
so god doesnt go around predicting or foreknowing people's individual choices, he just make sure the big picture gets accomplished. i can live with that. strategy over micro-management. but it would mean that obvious child's second option is true. well, to a certain extent. god can predict what will happen in the future, but not the individual that will cause such to happen. is that correct?

 It would not benefit mankind one bit to live like, say, an animal - where instinct takes him from one place to another. Man has inside him a living spirit and soul that does not belong here on earth. Since our inner-man is the real person that we are, then that real person came directly from God for the sole purpose of deciding for himself where he wants to go. Most of the time our spirit-man yearns for God in some way or another. But, during this cycle of temporary life we tend to want to gather information more of the carnal than of the spiritual - it's human nature to do so. That is why God has to keep His plan on a specific route. He knows what's best for us and how we can accomplish this greater good, but can do nothing but ask that we accept Him as our God and Savior and extend to us His blessings and perform those promises that He has already made.
 If He has to manipulate the powers of darkness in order to keep His plan on track, He'll do it. But with humans, He will not break His promise and will not remove the power of free will. The powers of darkness entered into Judas and manipulated his thoughts to betray Jesus. This God foreknew. To accomplish His Word, written to man earlier and documented in the Old Testament, God saw fit that it be done by Judas' own choosing. Here again, all things worked together for the good for those that loved God. And I believe it happens today - where God takes the bad things in life and works them to promote His kingdom.
canadianman77

you all seem to be missing the crux of my argument. To say that free will is god's "greatest" gift is one thing, but can a good god, who is completely and totally good, create evil? It is impossible. Evil is wholly outside of God, and if nothing exists (thus the ex nihilo section) then how can evil be created if not by God?
 
 This argument just blows away the traditional understanding of God as being "all good" or "all powerful" or "all knowing". We are not able to tell which one goes, just that AT LEAST ONE of them must go. Of course Christian understanding would say that none of them must go.
 
 The Catholic Church does have an interesting solution to this dilemma found in St. Augustine (Confessions 7:3-5).... deny that evil exists. Evil is the nothingness from which God created good. Evil is a lack... a deficiently of goodness (or God), to quote a leading Augustinian scholar, P.M. Farrell:"evil is described as privation of good... Privation is real - blindness, the lack of limb, the passing of colour from the decaying rose. This description will be found to be valid of evil universally."
 
 Now this is A reasonable explanation, but it would be of no comfort to evangelical/fundamentalist Christians who view evil as something that does exist (read Satan). Which means, that for those who do not want to take the Catholic exit strategy, my evil argument still holds water.

 Evil is not outside of god, he designated satan as the posterchild so to speak for evil, because it just so happened that satan was jealous of humans. After all, satan is just another child of god. Nothing more than a jealous angel. Possibly a rebellious teenager? Mayabe in the future, They will make amends, and the world will be a better place? HA! Yeah right! lmao!
epaphras_faith

There is no logical contradiction in saying that God is good and yet allows evil. Even being all knowing does not add to the contradicition. They are not mutually exclusive. The nature of God being good necessarily requires the existence of evil (within the physical universe). Outside of this universe perhaps different laws apply, but that cannot be known.
 
 Unker is correct in his logical analysis.
 
 Likewise, free choice is a necessary component of love (the ultimate good). Without free choice then it is obligation and not love. Hatred also requires choice. Both must exist. 
 
 God can be good AND create the possibility of evil (through choice). His nature as one of love requires it.

 Predestination as defined in the new testament is not a word that means a line is drawn and we follow the line. It mearly means that boundaries are drawn. Like me putting a fence around my yard and allowing my child to play in the yard. The child can go and do what they want, yet the boundaries are fixed. Predestination does not contradict free will either.
 
 Also, love and good are choices. They must be made. If there is no choice then it is obligation.

 Free will may be restricted or "impaired" as you say, but not non existent. There is nothing wrong with boundaries on our choices. No matter how hard we try, neither you nor I could ever choose to be a rock. It is not within our nature. We are not inanimate, even if we want to be. The boundaries that are given to us are that we must act in accordance with our nature, just as animals do. A lion cannot choose to be a bear and I cannot choose to be a lion. This does not eliminate free will, nor God's sovreignty. It mearly states the definitions of each.
canadianman77

 gravity has nothing to do with free will. there are certain consequences that are inevitable once an action is made. knowing the consequences afford us the information on which to base these choices. if i drop a rock, it will fall downward. if i plant an apple seed. it will grow into an apple tree. if i drink a lot of alcohol, ill get drunk. these are consequences to actinos. the actions themselves are what we choose to do, the consequences that follow are simply the aftermath of our actions. it does not in any way affect free will. in fact, it enhances free will because we can make informed decisions rather than every action being one of trial and error
